results.title: Wealth from coal
results.creator_credit: Realist Films and Edgar H. Anstey
results.brief_description: A study of the varied and versatile by-products of coal, which include: tar, constituents for explosives, disinfectants, plastics, dyes and sulfa drugs.

results.title: We were just too young
results.creator_credit: MTI Teleprograms, J. Gary Mitchell and John McDonald
results.brief_description: Janice and John were teen parents at 15 and 18, and two years later the reality of their situation has shattered their dreams. We see how their bad decisions and unrealistic expectations now weigh heavily on their lives and their 2 year old son’s.

results.title: We want goods and services
results.brief_description: Uses children’s experiences to show that people all want many things, that some are goods and some are services, that everyone is a consumer, and that it takes many people to produce goods and services. Suitable for lower secondary level.

results.title: We too can learn
results.brief_description: Tells how a group of mentally handicapped children learned to live together and share their experiences at a special national fitness camp. A new world opened to them; walking in the bush, simple nature study, swimming, cricket and group games conducted by sympathetic instructors.

results.title: We the jury
results.creator_credit: Triptych Films, Debra Annear and Jo Lane
results.brief_description: This program clearly defines the procedures involved in selecting a jury to serve in a criminal trial. The Victorian example is used to explain the various steps of jury service including: jury selection, how jurors may be challenged, how jurors may be excused form serving and swearing in a jury. Interviews with jurors, a judge and other legal personnel further explain the reasons behind the procedures, providing an insight into the role of the jury. Suitable for middle Secondary - Tertiary level students.

results.title: We stop here
results.brief_description: Describes life on the Aboriginal reserve of Palm Island in Queensland. Old men from the Dyirbal tribe tell stories of the massacres and poisoning of their people when they first came in contact with the white settlers.

results.title: We sing more than we cry
results.brief_description: For two centuries Acadians have been reliving the legacy of exile left to them by their ancestors in 1755. Here, following a brief look at that tragic legacy, are expressions in word, song and music of the present-day struggle to maintain a viable cultural identity. They include the bitter outpourings of Acadian youth, and the humorous music of happy old-timers who sing and fiddle in the traditional style of Acadian folk music. The theme song is performed by well-known singer Edith Butler, herself an Acadian.

results.title: We see it like this (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Eurfron Gwynne Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children Growing Up”.
In any form of self expression there is a development which is related to intellectual growth, physical growth and experience. To explore this, the program looks at the way in which children of different ages express their ideas of friendship.

results.title: We of the West Riding
results.creator_credit: Greenpark Productions, Ralph Keene and Ken Annakin
results.brief_description: Yorkshire, its people, factories and wild moorland scenery. We are shown the country in which the Bronte sisters were born and its influence on their famous novel. Finally the chorus of the Chapel Choir sings the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel’s “Messiah”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greenpark Productions, Ralph Keene and Ken Annakin
